audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker announcing he has something to tell the audience. His tone suggests a mix of seriousness and nervousness. He describes sitting at his computer when he saw something out of the corner of his eye. He's using a flashlight because it "might be scary," then begins showing the audience.

The clip begins with one male speaker introducing something to show.  He describes it as "something to see", repeated once. He then remarks in a surprised tone that "this thing is huge," and says he has never seen something like it before.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who sounds nervous. He starts by saying, "Look at it," then observes that something "looks like it wants to kill me," pointing out "the spikes on its legs." His tone indicates fear as he emphasizes its size and the fact that "it's alive."

The audio clip features a single male speaker, who sounds somewhat apprehensive, warning that "it better not move." He mentions filming video footage, then transitions into describing an object, possibly an animal, and its defense mechanisms. He explains that the back of the object is meant to resemble the front to help it "disguise, help itself from predators." Despite its menacing appearance, he assures listeners he's done his research.

The audio clip features one male speaker describing a "female...house centipede." He explains, in a conversational tone, that "you can tell by the very last two legs on it," noting the front and back, and emphasizing the length of the top two legs extending out. The clip ends abruptly without further audio.

The clip opens with a male speaker who initially states, "funny thing is, okay" in a casual tone. An interjection of "Oh shit" is followed by his observation of something moving, and a monstrous yet harmless creature. He notes, "Don't look harmless, does it? It's huge," but moves on to stating the point he wants to make. The rustling of what sounds like leaves is heard while the speaker says, "Make sure this damn thing ain't gonna try jumping on me." He identifies it as a tick and then addresses the audience as, "Talk, ladies and gentlemen," before the clip ends.

A male speaker explains that he looked something up online and says "it's harmless, extremely harmless. It's actually beneficial." He continues to explain that it eats ants, roaches, spiders, bees, and "anything," in a somewhat casual tone. Finally, he ends with the word, "So..."

The clip starts with someone talking in a casual, somewhat reassuring tone, telling listeners not to be alarmed if they see a certain creature in their house, explaining that it's actually providing pest control. The speaker acknowledges that this creature, which they describe as a "big scary looking centipede," looks frightening but insists it's harmless. There's a subtle shift as the person expresses that, even though it's harmless, it can be pretty scary looking.

The clip starts with the sound of movement, followed by a male speaker who thinks "it's... this particular one" doing pushups and "getting stronger as we speak". The speaker advises against trying to kill it because it's fast and mentions how it zoomed across the wall, scaring him.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating that something is "harmless." He explains that "they eat spiders, ants, roaches," and suggests that seeing them indicates the presence of other pests, noting they have ants downstairs. He also reiterates that the creature "eats spiders too."

The clip starts with a person speaking, contemplating how something harmless-seeming "can't bite me" while a spider can cause trouble. They then mention keeping the first thing, though initially in their room, but eventually deciding to relocate it to the basement, with the intention of it eating spiders. The speaker ends this segment by characterizing it as "just a little informing insight".

The clip begins with one male speaker advising listeners not to be alarmed if they see "one of these big things," explaining that it's fast and unable to harm them. The speaker then offers to prove it, saying he can "look it up real quick." He mentions "House Centipede" and the sound of typing follows as he presumably does so.

The audio clip starts with a male voice speaking, possibly describing a scene, followed by the speaker saying "Actually, I'll put a better title: are house centipedes dangerous to humans? That's what I put as the topic". The speaker is then heard saying "Okay", before proceeding with "Now, it says right here". It's followed by "Shows all these little pictures of them. It's the same as that thing." "And, let's see." The speaker continues talking. Near the end, a distinct thud sound can be heard.

The audio begins with a male speaker, seemingly reading aloud and stating "I'm doing some research on this thing." The speaker continues, reading about the predatory nature of something, listing arthropods such as "cockroaches, nymphs, flies, moths, bedbugs, crickets, silverfish, earwigs, and small spiders." His tone is informative, like sharing information.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing concern about "things you'd probably rather not have in your home," followed by him reading "Remarks" from an "approved site" called "Bug Guide." He states that it is "very useful" when identifying unfamiliar creatures. He reads that they "consider this beneficial to you and your home since they rid rid you of other pests." He continues by quoting the text, noting, "Alsonipedes are aggressive predators," but they're not considered dangerous to humans. Concluding the quote, he states that a bite is "probably no worse than a bee sting." He expresses nervousness, but states that he wants "that bad boy having my back," implying that it can stay and hunt spiders. He concludes with the word, "Insight".

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker adopting a casual tone as he describes something he refers to as "that sucker". He states he is actually quite scared. He describes the object he is scared of as "a big bug" but then backtracks by saying "I'm just kidding. I don't care". He finishes by saying "peace out". A distinct popping sound is then heard.
